commit_message:
Changed coobook name to openstack-image

Changed the cookbook name to openstack-image, fixed all tests, and
addressed attributes. Also addressed calls to external services,
primarily keystone -> openstack-identity.

All tests pass.

Change-Id: I6338342a570000b3fb0ae610f1a1bb5aa15ae3e9

commit_message:
Copy the RHEL6 eventlet workaround from Oslo

Tests in oslo-incubator now need the horrendous hack to workaround an
issue with eventlet on RHEL6. We've moved the patch_tox_venv tool
and redhat-eventlet.patch into oslo-incubator, so add them to
openstack-common.conf.

Change-Id: I1acfec282b64d7582144b155119bedb1741db2f7

commit_message:
Detach volume fails when using multipath iscsi

Enabled multipath for libvirt iscsi volume driver. Attach volume worked,
however, detach volume failed. It failed because it can't find multipath
device "/dev/mapper/xxxxxxxx" from connection_info and block device
mapping table.

The fix is to retrieve multipath device info dynamically at detach time.

Fixes: bug #1178893

Change-Id: I53a3888daef93b57bf7f57438f74cee05e794b52
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/70/28870/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: iscsi_properties = connection_info['data'] multipath_device = None if CONF.libvirt_iscsi_use_multipath: host_device = ("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-%s" % (iscsi_properties['target_portal'], iscsi_properties['target_iqn'], iscsi_properties.get('target_lun', 0))) self._rescan_multipath() multipath_device = self._get_multipath_device_name(host_device) multipath_device: block_devices = self.connection.get_all_block_devices() devices = [] for dev in block_devices: if "/mapper/" in dev: devices.append(dev) else: mpdev = self._get_multipath_device_name(dev) if mpdev: devices.append(mpdev) if not devices: # disconnect if no other multipath devices # disconnect if no other multipath devices with same iqn # else do not disconnect iscsi portals, # as they are used for other luns
deleted_lines: iscsi_properties = connection_info['data'] "mapper" in connection_info['data']['device_path']: devices = [dev for dev in self.connection.get_all_block_devices() if "/mapper/" in dev] if not devices: #disconnect if no other multipath devices #disconnect if no other multipath devices with same iqn #else do not disconnect iscsi portals, #as they are used for other luns

subject: Architecture property updated in snapshot libvirt
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-05-02 21:40:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5608190d0adc190fd54c835c02fa3ed0b9021976', 'message': 'Architecture property updated twice in snapshot

During an instance snapshot if the architecture property is defined
in the image it is updated twice in the snapshot image.
The snapshot is created with the medata values from the
"instance_system_metadata" table and then, if defined, the architecure
property is updated from the value in the base image in that moment.

There is no reason to treat this property differently from others.
Also, it didn't respect the "non_inheritable_image_properties" option.

This change removes the special behavior for the architecture property
in the libvirt driver during a snapshot.

Change-Id: Ic5b4e3d462c08df167e14522fa25a7cf857c6aad
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-05-08 19:30:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/19581a16f09472c5465973e929622fae79fd125a', 'message': 'Architecture property updated twice in snapshot

During an instance snapshot if the architecture property is defined
in the image it is updated twice in the snapshot image.
The snapshot is created with the medata values from the
"instance_system_metadata" table and then, if defined, the architecure
property is updated from the value in the base image in that moment.

There is no reason to treat this property differently from others.
Also, it didn't respect the "non_inheritable_image_properties" option.

This change removes the special behavior for the architecture property
in the libvirt driver during a snapshot.

Fixes: bug #1176173
Change-Id: Ic5b4e3d462c08df167e14522fa25a7cf857c6aad
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-05-08 20:37:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3847d0480bd02d2a62ddaf6be31070a6c5b20b1b', 'message': 'Architecture property updated twice in snapshot

During an instance snapshot if the architecture property is defined
in the image it is updated twice in the snapshot image.
The snapshot is created with the medata values from the
"instance_system_metadata" table and then, if defined, the architecure

commit_message:
Architecture property updated in snapshot libvirt

During an instance snapshot if the architecture property is defined
in the image it is updated twice in the snapshot image.
The snapshot is created with the metadata values from the
"instance_system_metadata" table and then, if defined, the architecure
property is updated from the value in the base image in that moment.

There is no reason to treat this property differently from others.
Also, it didn't respect the "non_inheritable_image_properties" option.

This change removes the special behavior for the architecture property
in the libvirt driver during a snapshot.

Fixes: bug #1176173
Change-Id: Ic5b4e3d462c08df167e14522fa25a7cf857c6aad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/10/28110/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: if 'architecture' in base.get('properties', {}): arch = base['properties']['architecture'] metadata['properties']['architecture'] = arch

commit_message:
Fix for missing multipath device name

Due to formatting changes in the multipath -l output
we were sometimes missing the device name for each of the
multipath devices which gave us a device of '/dev/'.  This
causes problems on detach.

Fixes Bug: #1180497

Change-Id: I6017dda149776624fac452140d3d0f5df3f5fd5a

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2013 NEC Corporation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json from tempest.common.rest_client import RestClient class ServicesClientJSON(RestClient): def __init__(self, config, username, password, auth_url, tenant_name=None): super(ServicesClientJSON, self).__init__(config, username, password, auth_url, tenant_name) self.service = self.config.compute.catalog_type def list_services(self): resp, body = self.get("os-services") body = json.loads(body) return resp, body['services'] def is_enable_service(self, binary, host): post_body = { 'binary': binary, 'host': host } post_body = json.dumps(post_body) resp, body = self.put("os-services/enable", post_body, self.headers) body = json.loads(body) return resp, body['service'] def is_disable_service(self, binary, host): post_body = { 'binary': binary, 'host': host } post_body = json.dumps(post_body) resp, body = self.put("os-services/disable", post_body, self.headers) body = json.loads(body) return resp, body['service']

subject: Skip IPv6 addresses in cname_lookup middleware.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-05-03 21:13:42.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/common/middleware/test_cname_lookup.py', 'swift/common/middleware/cname_lookup.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/e3da6b07a0729db9ba5bc6b09952add79206c7e5', 'message': 'Skip IPv6 addresses in cname_lookup middleware.

It already skips IPv4 addresses, and since IPv6 is the future of the
Internet*, we should probably do the right thing with those too.

* IPv6: Just two years away for over fifteen years!

Change-Id: I54f1db4e936fd38d05ac8b5c709efba76525b9d2
'}]
commit_message:
Skip IPv6 addresses in cname_lookup middleware.

It already skips IPv4 addresses, and since IPv6 is the future of the
Internet*, we should probably do the right thing with those too.

* IPv6: Just two years away for over fifteen years!

Change-Id: I54f1db4e936fd38d05ac8b5c709efba76525b9d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/01/28201/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, domain) try: socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET6, domain) return True except socket.error: return False

subject: blueprint cisco-plugin-exception-handling
revisions:
[{'number': 3, 'created': '2013-05-16 12:47:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/da80a55993ebf65120e886317ef36267164d08f8', 'message': "blueprint cisco-plugin-exception-handling

Improvements to exception handling in the Cisco plugins. Changes
include:

- Added mapping of Cisco exceptions to HTTP codes
  (extension to FAULT_MAP).
- Removed several unused Cisco exception definitions.
- Added several new Cisco exceptions for fault conditions.
- Added several rollbacks for various sequential operations, e.g.:
  * Create port: Nexus sub-plugin fails after OVS sub-plugin success
  * Create port: Nexus switch conig fails after adding binding to
                 Nexus binding database
  * Delete port: OVS sub-plugin fails after Nexus sub-plugin success
- Delete Port: Reversed order of OVS/Nexus sub-plugin calls so that
  it is done in the reverse order as is done for create port.
- Removed several empty except/raise blocks
- Delete network: Removed call to Nexus sub-plugin delete_network,
  since that is a no-op.
- Removed a block of unused code in model's create_network method.
- Added several unit testcases, including patching of OVS, Cisco
  and Nexus config.
- Remove CISCO_TEST configuration from cisco plugin
  config .ini file.

Change-Id: Iabdf4842aa2f0b090a90e2c565848290832b5197

commit_message:
blueprint cisco-plugin-exception-handling

Improvements to exception handling in the Cisco plugins. Changes
include:

- Added mapping of Cisco exceptions to HTTP codes
  (extension to FAULT_MAP).
- Removed several unused Cisco exception definitions.
- Added several new Cisco exceptions for fault conditions.
- Added several rollbacks for various sequential operations, e.g.:
  * Create port: Nexus sub-plugin fails after OVS sub-plugin success
  * Create port: Nexus switch conig fails after adding binding to
                 Nexus binding database
  * Delete port: OVS sub-plugin fails after Nexus sub-plugin success
- Delete Port: Reversed order of OVS/Nexus sub-plugin calls so that
  it is done in the reverse order as is done for create port.
- Removed several empty except/raise blocks
- Delete network: Removed call to Nexus sub-plugin delete_network,
  since that is a no-op.
- Removed a block of unused code in model's create_network method.
- Added several unit testcases, including patching of OVS, Cisco
  and Nexus config.
- Remove CISCO_TEST configuration from cisco plugin
  config .ini file.

Change-Id: Iabdf4842aa2f0b090a90e2c565848290832b5197

added_lines: class NetworkSegmentIDNotFound(exceptions.QuantumException): """Segmentation ID for network is not found.""" message = _("Segmentation ID for network %(net_id)s is not found.") class NexusHostUnknown(exceptions.QuantumException): """Failed to find the Nexus switch.""" message = _("Unable to find %(nexus_host)s.") class NexusConnectFailed(exceptions.QuantumException): """Failed to connect to Nexus switch.""" message = _("Unable to connect to Nexus %(nexus_host)s. Reason: %(doc)s.") class NexusConfigFailed(exceptions.QuantumException): """Failed to configure Nexus switch.""" message = _("Failed to configure Nexus: %(config)s. Reason: %(doc)s.") message = _("Nexus Port Binding %(port_id)s is not present.")
deleted_lines: class NetworksLimit(exceptions.QuantumException): """Total number of network objects limit has been hit.""" message = _("Unable to create new network. Number of networks" "for the system has exceeded the limit") class QoSLevelInvalidDelete(exceptions.QuantumException): """QoS is associated with a port profile, hence cannot be deleted.""" message = _("QoS level %(qos_id)s could not be deleted " "for tenant %(tenant_id)s since association exists") message = _("Nexus Port Binding %(port_id)s is not present") class NexusPortBindingAlreadyExists(exceptions.QuantumException): """NexusPort Binding alredy exists.""" message = _("Nexus Port Binding %(port_id)s already exists") class UcsmBindingNotFound(exceptions.QuantumException): """Ucsm Binding is not present.""" message = _("Ucsm Binding with ip %(ucsm_ip)s is not present") class UcsmBindingAlreadyExists(exceptions.QuantumException): """Ucsm Binding already exists.""" message = _("Ucsm Binding with ip %(ucsm_ip)s already exists") class DynamicVnicNotFound(exceptions.QuantumException): """Ucsm Binding is not present.""" message = _("Dyanmic Vnic %(vnic_id)s is not present") class DynamicVnicAlreadyExists(exceptions.QuantumException): """Ucsm Binding already exists.""" message = _("Dynamic Vnic with name %(device_name)s already exists") class BladeNotFound(exceptions.QuantumException): """Blade is not present.""" message = _("Blade %(blade_id)s is not present") class BladeAlreadyExists(exceptions.QuantumException): """Blade already exists.""" message = _("Blade with mgmt_ip %(mgmt_ip)s already exists") class InvalidAttach(exceptions.QuantumException): message = _("Unable to plug the attachment %(att_id)s into port " "%(port_id)s for network %(net_id)s. Association of " "attachment ID with port ID happens implicitly when " "VM is instantiated; attach operation can be " "performed subsequently.") class InvalidDetach(exceptions.QuantumException): message = _("Unable to unplug the attachment %(att_id)s from port " "%(port_id)s for network %(net_id)s. The attachment " "%(att_id)s does not exist.")

commit_message:
Metadata retrieving from sqlite must be str for key

Encode metadata key as utf8 if key is unicode when
retriving it from sqlite database.

Change-Id: I4ba11543d1bed17098b5e52dd768c75b403188a1
Fixes: bug #1172202
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/46/27446/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: uni_keys = [k for k in metadata.keys() if isinstance(k, unicode)] for k in uni_keys: sv = metadata[k] del metadata[k] metadata[k.encode('utf-8')] = sv

commit_message:
Pass the proper admin context to update_dhcp

Bug 1180111

Commit 14e2ed3ace769c4deaca3c48a2fa59863f637a5f introduced changes
to contexts passed around during resize. One of the calls to
update_dhcp was missed and was causing stack traces on
resize-revert.

Change-Id: Ib7bec51324c7bced009407af13a7fff7a724e020
(cherry picked from commit 42cc18da31ceb10ec0b26fe734e7556873f6fe71)

Improve ovs and linuxbridge agents rpc exception handling

Fixes bug 1053497

Change-Id: Id946542b204cf75586224f3749b0007cc2d6b3a7

added_lines: from quantum.openstack.common.rpc import common as rpc_common def test_port_update_plugin_rpc_failed(self): port = {'id': 1, 'network_id': 1, 'admin_state_up': True} with mock.patch.object(ovs_quantum_agent.LOG, 'exception') as log: with mock.patch.object(self.agent.int_br, 'get_vif_port_by_id', return_value='2'): with mock.patch.object(self.agent.plugin_rpc, 'update_device_up') as device_up: with mock.patch.object(self.agent, 'port_bound'): device_up.side_effect = rpc_common.Timeout self.agent.port_update(mock.Mock(), port=port) self.assertTrue(device_up.called) self.assertEqual(log.call_count, 1) with mock.patch.object(self.agent.plugin_rpc, 'update_device_down') as device_down: with mock.patch.object(self.agent, 'port_dead'): port['admin_state_up'] = False device_down.side_effect = rpc_common.Timeout self.agent.port_update(mock.Mock(), port=port) self.assertTrue(device_down.called) self.assertEqual(log.call_count, 2)

commit_message:
Remove the term 'syspanel' from docs

Since the refactorization of syspanel occurred at
the very early Folsom days, the docs should reflect this too.

Cherry-picked from I8539b0b8bda2f63366c6de75b1a010f52f07fd0e

Fixes bug 1179873

Change-Id: I890c41048ad2cb9f44a1dacce01c570746ce27db

  https://github.com/openstack/python-ceilometerclient/commit/453f4d2a

commit_message:
Fix mis-scoped Client class breaking CLI

Fixes bug 1180439

The change in importation in this commit:

  https://github.com/openstack/python-ceilometerclient/commit/453f4d2a

caused the ceilometer CLI to fail in all cases with:

  'module' object has no attribute 'Client'

due to the mis-scoping of ceilometerclient.client.Client
as ceilometerclient.Client.

Change-Id: I5ec30bf74233f758519810629763ccb70bb7af87
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ceilometerclient refs/changes/49/29249/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ceilometerclient import client as ceiloclient client = ceiloclient.Client(api_version, endpoint, **kwargs)

commit_message:
Add negative UT cases for subnet/GW create/update

When force_gateway_on_subnet is configured, ensure
that a GW with IP same as subnet, and BCAST GW IP
are rejected during subnet create. For subnet update,
ensure GW outside of subnet is rejected.

bug 1178675

Change-Id: Ice58f7e1be7966b247c165e52807405401e5a4ea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/16/28816/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_create_subnet_gw_outside_cidr_force_on_returns_400(self): def test_create_subnet_gw_of_network_force_on_returns_400(self): cfg.CONF.set_override('force_gateway_on_subnet', True) with self.network() as network: self._create_subnet(self.fmt, network['network']['id'], '10.0.0.0/24', 400, gateway_ip='10.0.0.0') def test_create_subnet_gw_bcast_force_on_returns_400(self): cfg.CONF.set_override('force_gateway_on_subnet', True) with self.network() as network: self._create_subnet(self.fmt, network['network']['id'], '10.0.0.0/24', 400, gateway_ip='10.0.0.255') def test_update_subnet_gw_outside_cidr_force_on_returns_400(self): cfg.CONF.set_override('force_gateway_on_subnet', True) with self.network() as network: with self.subnet(network=network) as subnet: data = {'subnet': {'gateway_ip': '100.0.0.1'}} req = self.new_update_request('subnets', data, subnet['subnet']['id']) res = req.get_response(self.api) self.assertEqual(res.status_int, 400)

commit_message:
relax amqplib and kombu version requirements

as nova did while ago.

this particular version of kombu doesn't work if newer msgpack happens
to be installed on the system.

bug 1178512

Change-Id: I2749623036723b5a772b1c4c01dc07437e421925

commit_message:
Fix logic in test_db_loadbalancer

Fix code to check HTTP error code before attempt to deserialize body

fixes bug 1180113

Change-Id: I1d75e0fe739dfa70ef415602e669319797af026f

subject: Fix linuxbridge RPC message format
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2013-05-16 06:06:40.000000000', 'files': ['quantum/plugins/linuxbridge/common/constants.py', 'quantum/tests/unit/linuxbridge/test_defaults.py', 'quantum/plugins/linuxbridge/common/config.py', 'quantum/plugins/linuxbridge/agent/linuxbridge_quantum_agent.py', 'quantum/tests/unit/linuxbridge/test_lb_quantum_agent.py', 'etc/quantum/plugins/linuxbridge/linuxbridge_conf.ini', 'quantum/plugins/linuxbridge/lb_quantum_plugin.py', 'quantum/tests/unit/linuxbridge/test_rpcapi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/56cac98626f1b25fd375b9c8d00294d6fb84496b', 'message': 'Fix linuxbridge RPC message format

The linuxbridge, openvswitch, and hyperv plugins all use the same
basic RPC interface between their plugins and L2 agents. But the
attributes describing a virtual network passed from the plugin to the
agent over this interface differed for historical reasons. The
openvswitch and hyperv plugins each pass network_type,
physical_network, and segmentation_id attributes, whereas the
linuxbridge plugin previously passed vlan_id and physical_network
attributes, using special vlan_id values to indicate flat or local
network types.

This patch changes the linuxbridge plugin to pass network_type and
segmentation_id attributes instead of the vlan_id attribute, bringing
its message formats into sync with the other plugins. RPC
compatibility is required for blueprint modular-l2 so that the ml2
plugin can work with all three existing types of L2 agent. This RPC
message format change is also required for blueprint
vxlan-linuxbridge.

Unlike the vxlan-linuxbridge patch on which it is based (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26516/), this patch does not bump the
linuxbridge RPC version number, as the ml2 plugin will require all
three L2 agents to use the same RPC version. Instead, the updated
linuxbridge agent maintains compatibility with old linuxbridge plugins
by accepting either the old or new attributes. There is also a
configuration option, currently turned on by default, to enable the
updated linuxbridge plugin to pass the vlan_id attribute expected by
old linuxbridge agents along with the new attributes. These message
format compatibility mechanisms are intended to aid during upgrades,
and can eventually be removed.

Change-Id: I7cc1c9f96b09db6bab2c7d9f2b30b79fa4dab919

commit_message:
Fix linuxbridge RPC message format

The linuxbridge, openvswitch, and hyperv plugins all use the same
basic RPC interface between their plugins and L2 agents. But the
attributes describing a virtual network passed from the plugin to the
agent over this interface differed for historical reasons. The
openvswitch and hyperv plugins each pass network_type,
physical_network, and segmentation_id attributes, whereas the
linuxbridge plugin previously passed vlan_id and physical_network
attributes, using special vlan_id values to indicate flat or local
network types.

This patch changes the linuxbridge plugin to pass network_type and
segmentation_id attributes instead of the vlan_id attribute, bringing
its message formats into sync with the other plugins. RPC
compatibility is required for blueprint modular-l2 so that the ml2
plugin can work with all three existing types of L2 agent. This RPC
message format change is also required for blueprint
vxlan-linuxbridge.

Unlike the vxlan-linuxbridge patch on which it is based (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26516/), this patch does not bump the
linuxbridge RPC version number, as the ml2 plugin will require all
three L2 agents to use the same RPC version. Instead, the updated
linuxbridge agent maintains compatibility with old linuxbridge plugins
by accepting either the old or new attributes. There is also a
configuration option, currently turned on by default, to enable the
updated linuxbridge plugin to pass the vlan_id attribute expected by
old linuxbridge agents along with the new attributes. These message
format compatibility mechanisms are intended to aid during upgrades,
and can eventually be removed.

Change-Id: I7cc1c9f96b09db6bab2c7d9f2b30b79fa4dab919

added_lines: from oslo.config import cfg def _test_lb_api(self, rpcapi, topic, method, rpc_method, expected_msg=None, **kwargs): if not expected_msg: expected_msg = rpcapi.make_msg(method, **kwargs) self.assertEqual(expected_retval, retval) self.assertEqual(expected_arg, arg) cfg.CONF.set_override('rpc_support_old_agents', False, 'AGENT') expected_msg = rpcapi.make_msg('port_update', port='fake_port', network_type='vlan', physical_network='fake_net', segmentation_id='fake_vlan_id') expected_msg=expected_msg, port='fake_port', physical_network='fake_net', vlan_id='fake_vlan_id') def test_port_update_old_agent(self): cfg.CONF.set_override('rpc_support_old_agents', True, 'AGENT') rpcapi = plb.AgentNotifierApi(topics.AGENT) expected_msg = rpcapi.make_msg('port_update', port='fake_port', network_type='vlan', physical_network='fake_net', segmentation_id='fake_vlan_id', vlan_id='fake_vlan_id') self._test_lb_api(rpcapi, topics.get_topic_name(topics.AGENT, topics.PORT, topics.UPDATE), 'port_update', rpc_method='fanout_cast', expected_msg=expected_msg,

Kernel VXLAN support for quantum openvswitch plugin (WIP)

blueprint openvswitch-kernel-vxlan

Change-Id: Ifed84c5d75efffdec9171d3e65d90a2efc33b507
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/48/27648/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class VxlanIPDevice(IPDevice): def __init__(self, name, vni, group, root_helper=None, namespace=None): super(VxlanIPDevice, self).__init__(name, root_helper=root_helper, namespace=namespace) self.vxlan = IpVxlanCommand(self, vni, group) def __eq__(self, other): return (other is not None and self.name == other.name and self.namespace == other.namespace) def __str__(self): return self.nameclass IpVxlanCommand(IpDeviceCommandBase): COMMAND = 'link' def __init__(self, parent, vni, group): super(IpVxlanCommand, self).__init__(parent) self.vni = vni self.group = group def add(self): self._as_root('add', self.name, 'type', 'vxlan', 'id', self.vni, 'group', self.group, use_root_namespace=True)

subject: Generic hardware driver interface for Quantum Plugins
revisions:
[{'number': 32, 'created': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'files': ['quantum/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_quantum_plugin.py', 'etc/quantum/hardware_driver/hardware_driver.ini', 'quantum/common/hardware_driver/__init__.py', 'setup.py', 'quantum/common/hardware_driver/drivers/dummy.py', 'quantum/tests/unit/hardware_driver/test_arista_hardware_driver.py', 'quantum/tests/unit/hardware_driver/__init__.py', 'quantum/common/hardware_driver/drivers/arista.py', 'quantum/common/hardware_driver/drivers/__init__.py', 'tools/pip-requires', 'quantum/common/hardware_driver/driver_adapter.py', 'quantum/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/3e7e0c0e6540_added_hardware_drive.py', 'quantum/common/hardware_driver/driver_api.py', 'quantum/tests/unit/hardware_driver/test_hardware_driver_adapter.py', 'etc/quantum/hardware_driver/arista_driver.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/eebc64a5d371e64d2128385398f32b9525faef15', 'message': "Generic hardware driver interface for Quantum Plugins

This patch describes a generic hardware driver interface which may be used within
the Quantum Plugins which will enable support for different hardware backends
for L2 network segregation (VLANs, tunneling, etc.). Currently only the
OVSPlugin has been modified to use this hardware driver interface, but in future
other plugins may be able to use this interface.

This may be useful for existing data centers with hardware switches which needs
to be used along with Openstack infrastructure. In this case a hardware vendor
may introduce a hardware driver which will allow using vendor's hardware to be
used within Openstack, along with virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the Vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff also includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

There is a related one line change needed in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py,
allocate_for_instance() to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to
Quantum create_port().

Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
Change-Id: Ibccb032a433a81d9facdadce04840841ee4b0c20

Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
Change-Id: Ibccb032a433a81d9facdadce04840841ee4b0c20
"}, {'number': 21, 'created': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/61b0650cea9d6a1e1f31073880b800d8ff5fb1f7', 'message': "Generic hardware driver interface for Quantum Plugins

This patch describes a generic hardware driver interface which may be used within
the Quantum Plugins which will enable support for different hardware backends
for L2 network segregation (VLANs, tunneling, etc.). Currently only the
OVSPlugin has been modified to use this hardware driver interface, but in future
other plugins may be able to use this interface.

This may be useful for existing data centers with hardware switches which needs
to be used along with Openstack infrastructure. In this case a hardware vendor
may introduce a hardware driver which will allow using vendor's hardware to be
used within Openstack, along with virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the Vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff also includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

There is a related one line change needed in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py,
allocate_for_instance() to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to
Quantum create_port().

The related review is as at: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21141/

Change-Id: Ibccb032a433a81d9facdadce04840841ee4b0c20
Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices

This may be useful for existing data centers with hardware switches which needs
to be used along with Openstack infrastructure. In this case a hardware vendor
may introduce the OVS plugin extension which will allow using vendor's hardware
within Openstack along with Open vSwitch virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the open vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

There is a related one line change needed in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py,
allocate_for_instance() to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to

may introduce the OVS plugin extension which will allow using vendor's hardware
within Openstack along with Open vSwitch virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the open vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

Change-Id: Ibccb032a433a81d9facdadce04840841ee4b0c20
Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
"}]
commit_message:
Generic hardware driver interface for Quantum Plugins

This patch describes a generic hardware driver interface which may be used within
the Quantum Plugins which will enable support for different hardware backends
for L2 network segregation (VLANs, tunneling, etc.). Currently only the
OVSPlugin has been modified to use this hardware driver interface, but in future
other plugins may be able to use this interface.

This may be useful for existing data centers with hardware switches which needs
to be used along with Openstack infrastructure. In this case a hardware vendor
may introduce a hardware driver which will allow using vendor's hardware to be
used within Openstack, along with virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the Vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff also includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

There is a related one line change needed in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py,
allocate_for_instance() to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to
Quantum create_port().

Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
Change-Id: Ibccb032a433a81d9facdadce04840841ee4b0c20

commit_message:
Add a base workflow task management library + supporting utilities.

In order to perform basic workflow tasks there first needs
to be basic constructs that allow for tasks to be applied and
reverted and resources to be locked (so that they can not
be simulatenously used).

Change-Id: Ibf6013da923342062d0aee9e509da5e1dd2a7069
Implements: blueprint structured-state-management-core-library

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import abc class Task(object): """An abstraction that defines a potential piece of work that can be applied and can be reverted to undo the work as a single unit. """ __metaclass__ = abc.ABCMeta def __str__(self): return "Task: %s" % (self.__class__.__name__) @abc.abstractmethod def apply(self, context, *args, **kwargs): """Activate a given task which will perform some operation and return. This method can be used to apply some given context and given set of args and kwargs to accomplish some goal. Note that the result that is returned needs to be serializable so that it can be passed back into this task if reverting is triggered.""" raise NotImplementedError() def revert(self, context, result, cause): """Revert this task using the given context, result that the apply provided as well as any information which may have caused said reversion.""" pass

subject: Speed up tests through more DB caching
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-05-08 13:25:01.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/dbcache.py', 'nova/test.py', 'nova/tests/test_dbcache.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0ee43f5777ac90834b4cdb398e9562650e95eafd', 'message': "Speed up tests through more DB caching

Caches the result of a series of DB statements run on a connection,
then replays them for the next connection that runs the same series.

It is a work in progress and causes test failures still.

I gathered some stastics of similar sql statements executed by the
tests, and there are some good cases where caching the db results like
this should help.

For example, the same 8 statements may be executed in sequence by 101
different tests (this is an actual case found when testing this).
With the caching, it'll mean simply 8 integer in a dict lookups, instead
of actually executing the sql in sqlite.

If it turns out that it doesn't help too much the next step may be
intelligently storing the actual state of the DB (using sqlite backup
api) ..

Change-Id: Ie10dad1479b83e16fbd2f2902949931567b39784
"}]
commit_message:
Speed up tests through more DB caching

Caches the result of a series of DB statements run on a connection,
then replays them for the next connection that runs the same series.

It is a work in progress and causes test failures still.

I gathered some stastics of similar sql statements executed by the
tests, and there are some good cases where caching the db results like
this should help.

For example, the same 8 statements may be executed in sequence by 101
different tests (this is an actual case found when testing this).
With the caching, it'll mean simply 8 integer in a dict lookups, instead
of actually executing the sql in sqlite.

If it turns out that it doesn't help too much the next step may be
intelligently storing the actual state of the DB (using sqlite backup
api) ..

Change-Id: Ie10dad1479b83e16fbd2f2902949931567b39784
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/28547/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2013 Openstack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import testtools import mox from nova.tests import dbcache class TestDBCache(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestDBCache, self).setUp() self.mox = mox.Mox() self.connection = self.mox.CreateMockAnything() self.cursor = self.mox.CreateMockAnything() self.cache = dbcache.Cache() self.caching_conn = dbcache.CachingConnection(self.connection, self.cache) def test_get_cursor(self): self.connection.cursor().AndReturn(self.cursor) self.mox.ReplayAll() caching_cursor = self.caching_conn.cursor() self.assertEqual(self.cursor, caching_cursor.cursor) def test_execute(self): self.connection.cursor().AndReturn(self.cursor) self.cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) self.cursor.fetchall().AndReturn(['result']) self.mox.ReplayAll() caching_cursor = self.caching_conn.cursor() caching_cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) def test_fetchone(self): self.connection.cursor().AndReturn(self.cursor) self.cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) self.cursor.fetchall().AndReturn(['a', 'b', 'c']) self.mox.ReplayAll() caching_cursor = self.caching_conn.cursor() caching_cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) self.assertEqual('a', caching_cursor.fetchone()) self.assertEqual('b', caching_cursor.fetchone()) self.assertEqual('c', caching_cursor.fetchone()) self.assertEqual(None, caching_cursor.fetchone()) def test_fetchmany(self): self.connection.cursor().AndReturn(self.cursor) self.cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) self.cursor.fetchall().AndReturn(['a', 'b', 'c']) self.mox.ReplayAll() caching_cursor = self.caching_conn.cursor() caching_cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) self.assertEqual(['a', 'b'], caching_cursor.fetchmany(2)) self.assertEqual(['c'], caching_cursor.fetchmany(2)) self.assertEqual([], caching_cursor.fetchmany(2)) def test_fetchall(self): self.connection.cursor().AndReturn(self.cursor) self.cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) self.cursor.fetchall().AndReturn(['a', 'b', 'c']) self.mox.ReplayAll() caching_cursor = self.caching_conn.cursor() caching_cursor.execute('some sql', ('param')) self.assertEqual(['a', 'b', 'c'], caching_cursor.fetchall()) self.assertEqual([], caching_cursor.fetchall()) def test_caching(self): self.connection.cursor().AndReturn(self.cursor) self.cursor.execute('create tables', ('param')) self.cursor.fetchall().AndReturn([]) self.cursor.execute('get something', ('param')) self.cursor.fetchall().AndReturn(['a', 'b', 'c']) self.mox.ReplayAll() caching_cursor = self.caching_conn.cursor() caching_cursor.execute('create tables', ('param')) caching_cursor.execute('get something', ('param')) self.assertEqual(['a', 'b', 'c'], caching_cursor.fetchall()) caching_cursor.execute('get something', ('param')) # Subsquent calls should not call the db cursor, but still return the # same result self.assertEqual(['a', 'b', 'c'], caching_cursor.fetchall()) caching_cursor.execute('get something', ('param')) self.assertEqual(['a', 'b', 'c'], caching_cursor.fetchall())

commit_message:
Wrong memory and storage computing in resource tracer

There is an error in available resource computing logic within nova
resource tracker, that caused available resource counted the all
instances including error status one.

Fixes bug: 1169929

Change-Id: Ibebddc31461e691816d828c53465a0d81b7128a5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Fix endpoints[0] hard coded problem in novaclient/v1_1/shell.py function
do_endpoints

Changes: read os_region_name from args, if os_region_name is empty,
print all endpoints. else only print matched endpoints.

Fix bug 1169051

Change-Id: I3d2a804066197f5fd4995ce35271be513ef58681

commit_message:
Move bin/swift to an entrypoint.

It makes it easier for all of the tools to do their jobs when the code
is inside of the swiftclient package.

Change-Id: I8de85d7dc6f4a14574c7f1beb63e9640f17146e1

commit_message:
Use a property decorator to lazily load the apis.

Instead of having special per instance logic to load the
api objects we should prefer to use the more pythonic
extension to the standard @property to lazily load and
return the properties when they are first accessed.

Change-Id: I6656f77c1cf19a484607de662b6f25fa02e0bad3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/77/27877/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functools class lazy_property(property): def __init__(self, functor): self._value = None self._functor = functor self._was_provided = False functools.wraps(self._functor)(self) def __get__(self, obj, obj_type=None): if self._was_provided: return self._value self._value = self._functor(obj) self._was_provided = True return self._value @lazy_property def security_group_api(self): return openstack_driver.get_openstack_security_group_driver() @lazy_property return network.API() @lazy_property def compute_api(self): # NOTE(danms): We need to instantiate our compute_api on first use # to avoid the circular dependency that exists between our init # and compute_api's return compute_api.API()
deleted_lines: self.security_group_api = ( openstack_driver.get_openstack_security_group_driver()) self._network_api = None self._compute_api = None @property if self._network_api is None: self._network_api = network.API() return self._network_api @property def compute_api(self): if self._compute_api is None: self._compute_api = compute_api.API() return self._compute_api

commit_message:
Move tests/ dir into swiftclient/.

tests is not actually a top-level module. There is one of those in the
Python source tree, in fact. These are tests for swiftclient, which
means from a codepath perspective, they code in them belongs to the
swiftclient module.

Change-Id: Id4c0242925ffe14430d115fc797efd770fd0aa11

added_lines:
GET'> PUT'> POST'> DELETE'> '> '> ]>
The ExtraRoute Extension ExtraRoute You can setup route configutaion on the Router using this this extension. This extension extends Router resource adding new attribute route. OVS plugin, linuxbridge plugin, metaplugin, NEC plugin, Ryu plugin supports this extension. Note NextHopIp should be connected via one router interface. This is why confiration of route property is allowd only on Update time.
Router Attributes
Attribute Type Required CRUD C. Use the attribute in create operations. R. This attribute is returned in response to show and list operations. U. You can update the value of this attribute. D. You can delete the value of this attribute. Default Value Validation Constraints Notes
routes dict No U None Dict should be this form. {'nexthop':NextHopIP, 'destination':CIDR} Extra route configration
Update Extra route Verb URI Description &PUT; /routers/router_id Update logical router with routes attribute. Normal Response Code: 200 Error Response Codes: Unauthorized (401), Bad Request (400), Not Found (404), Conflict (409) This operation configures extra routes on the logical router. NextHop address should be connected with the logical Router, otherwise quantum responds 400 Bad Request Update routes attribute router: Request PUT /v2.0/routers/babc8173-46f6-4b6f-8b95-38c1683a4e22.json {"router": { "routes": [{"nexthop": "10.1.0.10", "destination": "40.0.1.0/24"}] } } Update routes: Response {"router": {"status": "ACTIVE", "external_gateway_info": {"network_id": "5c26e0bb-a9a9-429c-9703-5c417a221096"}, "name": "router1", "admin_state_up": true, "tenant_id": "936fa220b2c24a87af51026439af7a3e", "routes": [{"nexthop": "10.1.0.10", "destination": "40.0.1.0/24"}], "id": "babc8173-46f6-4b6f-8b95-38c1683a4e22"} }

Change-Id: Ia3d17e76c94f9f324998bced21b9f5ace55c3f2d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/68/29068/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Install bounded pep8/pyflakes first, then let flake8 install deps = pep8==1.4.5 pyflakes==0.7.2 flake8==2.0 hacking>=0.5.3,<0.6

subject: Implementation of replication servers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-01-14 11:35:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/91b7a5037c8f7d65bd48480f83e341a077f605d9', 'message': 'Implementation of replication servers

Support separate replication ip address:
- Added new function in utils. This function provides ability
  to select separate IP address for replication service.
- Db_replicator and object replicators were changed.
  Replication processe uses new function now.

Replication network parameters:
- Replication network fields (replication_ip, replication_port)
  support was added to device dictionary in swift-ring-builder script.
- Changes were made to support new fields in search, show and set_info
  functions.

Implementation of replication servers:
- Separate replication servers were implemented.
- Starting scripts and configs for replication servers were added.
- Algorithm of selecting config file for *-replicator were
  changed.
- Allowed_methods attribute was added in account-, container-,
  object-server.

Change-Id: Ie9af5bdcdf9241c355e36053ca4adfe49dc35bd0
Implements: blueprint dedicated-replication-network

commit_message:
Implementation of replication servers

Support separate replication ip address:
- Added new function in utils. This function provides ability
  to select separate IP address for replication service.
- Db_replicator and object replicators were changed.
  Replication process uses new function now.

Replication network parameters:
- Replication network fields (replication_ip, replication_port)
  support was added to device dictionary in swift-ring-builder script.
- Changes were made to support new fields in search, show and set_info
  functions.

Implementation of replication servers:
- Separate replication servers use the same code as normal replication
  servers, but with replication_server parameter = True.  When using a
  separate replication network, the non-replication servers set
  replication_server = False.  When there is no separate replication
  network (the default case), replication_server is not included in the config.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ie9af5bdcdf9241c355e36053ca4adfe49dc35bd0
Implements: blueprint dedicated-replication-network

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2010-2012 OpenStack, LLC. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. """ Tests for swift.object_replication_server """ import unittest import os from tempfile import mkdtemp from shutil import rmtree from swift.common import utils from swift.common.utils import mkdirs from swift.obj import server as object_server from swift.obj import replication_server class TestObjectReplicationController(unittest.TestCase): """ Test swift.obj.replication_server.ObjectReplicationController """ def setUp(self): """ Set up for testing swift.obj.replication_server.ObjectReplicationController """ utils.HASH_PATH_SUFFIX = 'endcap' self.testdir = \ os.path.join(mkdtemp(), 'tmp_test_object_replication_server_' 'ObjectReplicationController') mkdirs(os.path.join(self.testdir, 'sda1', 'tmp')) conf = {'devices': self.testdir, 'mount_check': 'false'} self.object_replication_controller = \ replication_server.ObjectReplicationController(conf) self.object_replication_controller.bytes_per_sync = 1 def tearDown(self): """ Tear down for testing swift.obj.replication_server.ObjectReplicationController """ rmtree(os.path.dirname(self.testdir)) def test_is_subclass(self): """ Test that ObjectReplicationController is subclass of ObjectController """ self.assertTrue(issubclass( replication_server.ObjectReplicationController, object_server.ObjectController)) def test_allowed_methods(self): """ Test swift.replication_server. ObjectReplicationController.allowed_methods """ allowed_methods = self.object_replication_controller.allowed_methods self.assertEquals(allowed_methods, ['REPLICATE']) if __name__ == '__main__': unittest.main()

commit_message:
solidfire: Make sure src_uuid is passed correctly

src_uuid wasn't passed correctly as an attribute because
the variable was wrongly quoted and couldn't be interpolated.

Fixes: bug #1180611
Change-Id: If22dda162a28138cf447ce12bbe061f623e6d076

commit_message:
Restore test dependency on Ming

Add Ming to the dependency list so we get MIM for in-memory
testing with the storage API.

Fixes bug 1176017

Change-Id: Ib1d87cab4b7616af354c4b0f937eb734b9dc9d1a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

subject: Remove calls to policy.check from plugin logic
revisions:
[{'number': 9, 'created': '2013-05-16 02:09:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c4eaec86fb56400ec10a4de6e20e0421fd141be0', 'message': "Remove calls to policy.check from plugin logic

Blueprint make-authz-orthogonal

This patch implements part #3 of this blueprint, according to its
specification.
It does so by allowing the view generator in the API layer to strip
off fields which do not satify authorization policies.
Also, some checks in unit tests for plugins relied on the
capability of the plugin to invoke directly the policy engine.
This checks have been removed and replaced by equivalent unit tests.
Finally, this patch required changes to most test cases for API
extensions in order to ensure the resource attribute map was
updated with the extension's attributes

Change-Id: I1ef94a8a628d34697254b68d7a539bd1c636876e

commit_message:
Remove calls to policy.check from plugin logic

Blueprint make-authz-orthogonal

This patch implements part #3 of this blueprint, according to its
specification.
It does so by allowing the view generator in the API layer to strip
off fields which do not satify authorization policies.
Also, some checks in unit tests for plugins relied on the
capability of the plugin to invoke directly the policy engine.
This checks have been removed and replaced by equivalent unit tests.
Finally, this patch required changes to most test cases for API
extensions in order to ensure the resource attribute map was
updated with the extension's attributes

Change-Id: I1ef94a8a628d34697254b68d7a539bd1c636876e

commit_message:
Deprecating old dot path locations for Folsom configs

In grizzly, we made a lot of structure changes. This deprecates the old
locations so the dot paths in old configs still work but give warnings
in the logs of what needs to be updated.

Fixes: bug #1168573
Change-Id: I7b1754b0e59a923afa623871fc3be07362bf1bdc

commit_message:
Set the default pipline config file for tests

Some of the tests that use a pipeline as a side-effect
(mostly the API tests, now that we create a pipline
automatically in the Pecan hook) only ran if there was
a config file in the production location. This change
resets the default for the pipeline_cfg_file option
to a location that is valid while the tests are running,
even if there is no configuration file in /etc/ceilometer.

Change-Id: I1164df85fd65002660d48d8d76cbfc4a3664f0ea
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Update KillFilter to stop at '\0' for readlink() function.

Python's readlink() implementation doesn't stop at '\0' when reading
file path. Thus after dnsmasq upgrade, it may return something like
'/usr/sbin/dnsmasq\03453 (deleted)', while C's or Shell's readlink()
return '/usr/sbin/dnsmasq'. This patch fixes this problem by cutting
the readlink() results with '\0', so that KillFilter could get correct
path.

Bug 1179793

Change-Id: I7354941e0508e019c8c9b63b87ad39f52ccb51ca

subject: Support capping message versions in the client.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-05-15 20:41:43.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/rpc/test_proxy.py', 'openstack/common/rpc/common.py', 'openstack/common/rpc/proxy.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/aa89d8b27a86abc1ba84133c655a49fa3ccda798', 'message': "Support capping message versions in the client.

When doing a rolling upgrade, we need to be able to tell all rpc clients
to hold off on sending newer versions of messages until all nodes
understand the new message version.  This patch adds the oslo component
of this.

It's quite simple.  The rpc proxy just stores the version cap and will
raise an exception if code ever tries to send a message that exceeds
this cap.

Allowing the cap to be configured and generating different types of
messages based on the configured value is the hard part here, but that

Implements blueprint rpc-version-control.

Change-Id: Ia69db03a80dc3b1c63d52c7e163ea3cfec80c882
"}]
commit_message:
Support capping message versions in the client.

When doing a rolling upgrade, we need to be able to tell all rpc clients
to hold off on sending newer versions of messages until all nodes
understand the new message version.  This patch adds the oslo component
of this.

It's quite simple.  The rpc proxy just stores the version cap and will
raise an exception if code ever tries to send a message that exceeds
this cap.

Allowing the cap to be configured and generating different types of
messages based on the configured value is the hard part here, but that
is left up to the project using the rpc library.

Implements blueprint rpc-version-control.

Change-Id: Ia69db03a80dc3b1c63d52c7e163ea3cfec80c882
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/90/29290/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2012-2013 Red Hat, Inc.from openstack.common.rpc import common as rpc_common def __init__(self, topic, default_version, version_cap=None): :param version_cap: Optionally cap the maximum version used for sent messages. self.version_cap = version_cap v = vers if vers else self.default_version if (self.version_cap and not rpc_common.version_is_compatible(self.version_cap, v)): raise rpc_common.RpcVersionCapError(version=self.version_cap) msg['version'] = v
deleted_lines: # Copyright 2012 Red Hat, Inc. def __init__(self, topic, default_version): msg['version'] = vers if vers else self.default_version

commit_message:
Revert "Include list of attached volumes with instance info"

This reverts commit dd66f235ecf2ff67819917ee07bcb0ea13a1b17b.

This changed the core servers API without doing it as an API extension,
so it's not an acceptable change as written.

Change-Id: I3787060583de1371e366647d38d69f37746317d5

commit_message:
NetApp server tunneling fix.

NetApp vserver/vfiler api tunneling in concurrent requests
can cause routing request to incorrect servers in race conditions.
This fixes the api and driver for the mentioned situations.

bug 1176759

Change-Id: Id283822e4d1553daed4e6d690ec36f2edfbcf2b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/94/28294/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Get the vfiler to use in tunneling.""" """Set the vfiler to use if tunneling gets enabled.""" """Get the vserver to use in tunneling.""" """Set the vserver to use if tunneling gets enabled.""" def invoke_elem(self, na_element, enable_tunnelling=False): request = self._create_request(na_element, enable_tunnelling) def invoke_successfully(self, na_element, enable_tunnelling=False): """Invokes api and checks execution status as success. Need to set enable_tunnelling to True explicitly to achieve it. This helps to use same connection instance to enable or disable tunnelling. The vserver or vfiler should be set before this call otherwise tunnelling remains disabled. """ result = self.invoke_elem(na_element, enable_tunnelling) def _create_request(self, na_element, enable_tunnelling=False): if enable_tunnelling: self._enable_tunnel_request(netapp_elem) netapp_elem.add_child_elem(na_element) request_d = netapp_elem.to_string() request = urllib2.Request( self._get_url(), data=request_d, headers={'Content-Type': 'text/xml', 'charset': 'utf-8'}) return request def _enable_tunnel_request(self, netapp_elem): """Enables vserver or vfiler tunneling. commit_message:
Implement cloned volume for the RBD driver

This adds the support for cloned volume to the RBD driver. This is perform by the
create option --source-volid. Since the clone is pure copy of a volume,
we don't use the clone capability from RBD and simply copy the source
image.

Change-Id: I3b73bc77b74767ffe3583422f56b3603594589ce
Implements: blueprint implement-cloned-volume-for-rbd

commit_message:
Hide lock_prefix argument using synchronized_with_prefix()

The lockfile module has a new convenience API which sets the lockfile prefix
Using this API, the prefix is not required everytime synchronized is used.

commit_message:
Fixed do_create() in v2 shell.

Previously when creating a volume v2 shell was able to create
it but then failed to display volume properties. Instead of that
it displayed a non-informative error message. This patch fixes
the problem.

Change-Id: I1d3f9127ddd793a905527660b64ffe8c28f20f1d

commit_message:
Fix missing pieces filled in by boot-stack.

Boot-stack accidentally installs nova-common along with novnc, which
took care of these things accidentally.

Fixes bug #1180241

commit_message:
Fix for running /etc/rc.local on Fedora

With systemd rc.local lives in /etc/rc.d and is only run
if the rc-local service is enabled.

This change creates a /etc/rc.d/rc.local symlink, and modifies img-functions
prepare_first_boot to tolerate an initially missing /etc/rc.local.

Fixes bug #1179674

Change-Id: I7e6102b62224950c1de5d48205dc4feff60f9389
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/16/29016/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add missing tests for db.fixed_ip_*(). functions.

Added new tests for fixed_ip*() functions.
Function fixed_ip_create() should return FixedIp instance rather than
FixedIp.address, because it is used in a tests later.
Fix calls of fixed_ip_create() respectively.

blueprint test-db-api

commit_message:
Perform mount check after REST params valid on PUT

All the other methods (POST, GET, HEAD, DELETE and REPLICATE) first
validate the REST parameters and headers before performing the mount
check. Do the same for PUT.

Change-Id: I6e5f34cc65b57662b7f88224ca0e1501787e0f43
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
An element for putting SELinux in permissive mode

This is useful for selinux debugging, so is most useful in its own

commit_message:
install redhat-lsb before pre-install.d baseline-tools

baseline-tools expects lsb_release (although tolerates it not being there)

Order needs to be 01-override-yum-arch, 02-lsb, 03-baseline-tools
hence the renames.

Possibly lsb_release isn't cared enough about to do this.

Change-Id: I03abffb1ab2f560e746ba4ffd407605de31f4930

commit_message:
install redhat-lsb-core instead of redhat-lsb

The later pulls in most of a desktop. The former still pulls in a lot
but significantly less, and still provides lsb_release.

commit_message:
Implement CinderVolume.FnGetAtt

This allows retrieving Cinder properties in the template.

Change-Id: Id20d4d2cbd5f78ad4412f6260d66b43bd2ef6596
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/72/28672/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_cinder_fn_getatt(self): fv = FakeVolume('creating', 'available', availability_zone='zone1', size=1, snapshot_id='snap-123', display_name='name', display_description='desc', volume_type='lvm', metadata={'key': 'value'}, source_volid=None, status='available', created_at='2013-02-25T02:40:21.000000') stack_name = 'test_volume_stack' clients.OpenStackClients.cinder().MultipleTimes().AndReturn( self.cinder_fc) self.cinder_fc.volumes.create( size=u'1', availability_zone='nova', display_description='%s.DataVolume' % stack_name, display_name='%s.DataVolume' % stack_name).AndReturn(fv) eventlet.sleep(1).AndReturn(None) self.cinder_fc.volumes.get('vol-123').MultipleTimes().AndReturn(fv) self.m.ReplayAll() t = template_format.parse(volume_template) t['Resources']['DataVolume']['Properties'] = { 'size': '1', 'availability_zone': 'nova', } stack = parse_stack(t, stack_name=stack_name) resource = vol.CinderVolume('DataVolume', t['Resources']['DataVolume'], stack) scheduler.TaskRunner(resource.create)() self.assertEqual(u'vol-123', resource.FnGetAtt('id')) self.assertEqual(u'zone1', resource.FnGetAtt('availability_zone')) self.assertEqual(u'1', resource.FnGetAtt('size')) self.assertEqual(u'snap-123', resource.FnGetAtt('snapshot_id')) self.assertEqual(u'name', resource.FnGetAtt('display_name')) self.assertEqual(u'desc', resource.FnGetAtt('display_description')) self.assertEqual(u'lvm', resource.FnGetAtt('volume_type')) self.assertEqual(u"{'key': 'value'}", resource.FnGetAtt('metadata')) self.assertEqual(u'None', resource.FnGetAtt('source_volid')) self.assertEqual(u'available', resource.FnGetAtt('status')) self.assertEqual(u'2013-02-25T02:40:21.000000', resource.FnGetAtt('created_at')) error = self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidTemplateAttribute, resource.FnGetAtt, 'unknown') self.assertEqual( 'The Referenced Attribute (DataVolume unknown) is incorrect.', str(error)) def __init__(self, initial_status, final_status, **attrs): for key, value in attrs.iteritems(): setattr(self, key, value)

commit_message:
Clean up VPC unit tests

 - Ensure that stacks are cleaned up on failure.
 - Add a test for the case where an something other than a valid reference
   is passed as the GroupSet.
 - Add a test for the case where no GroupSet is passed.

Ref bug #1164913

Change-Id: I7637ed7969f23662643756da4a49627a2b40de20
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/30/29230/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: test_template_error_no_ref = ''' HeatTemplateFormatVersion: '2012-12-12' Resources: the_vpc: Type: AWS::EC2::VPC Properties: {CidrBlock: '10.0.0.0/16'} the_subnet: Type: AWS::EC2::Subnet Properties: CidrBlock: 10.0.0.0/24 VpcId: {Ref: the_vpc} AvailabilityZone: moon the_nic: Type: AWS::EC2::NetworkInterface Properties: PrivateIpAddress: 10.0.0.100 SubnetId: {Ref: the_subnet} GroupSet: - INVALID-NO-REF ''' try: resource = stack['the_nic'] self.assertResourceState(resource, 'dddd') self.assertEqual(resource.UPDATE_REPLACE, resource.handle_update({})) finally: stack.delete() self.m.VerifyAll() def test_network_interface_error_no_ref(self): self.mock_create_network() self.mock_create_subnet() self.mock_show_subnet() self.mock_delete_subnet() self.mock_delete_network() self.m.ReplayAll() stack = self.create_stack(self.test_template_error_no_ref) try: self.assertEqual(stack.CREATE_FAILED, stack.state) self.assertEqual(stack['the_nic'].CREATE_FAILED, stack['the_nic'].state) reason = stack['the_nic'].state_description self.assertTrue(reason.startswith('InvalidTemplateAttribute:')) finally: stack.delete() self.m.VerifyAll()

subject: Use python logging for loguserdata.py, log to console
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-05-14 23:50:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/a47a8125b319bd1785879ee2dba51d3eff25d893', 'message': 'Use python logging for loguserdata.py, log to console

Python logging is configured with a stream handler and should
also replicate the previous logging to 0600 /var/log/heat-provision.log

By logging to a stream handler cloud-init will write to its log,
which will show up in the server console log. This means that heat
provisioning can now be monitored without needing to log in with:

nova console-log <servername>

This change also touches the file /var/lib/heat-cfntools/provision-finished
instead of also writing a datestamp to it, which is redundant.

Change-Id: Id0312bd2216a83753df601b17ad16d5355cdb11d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-05-14 23:57:50.000000000', 'files': ['heat/cloudinit/loguserdata.py', 'heat/tests/test_loguserdata.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/05ca181e9e9eb864a96bdab8bc19734ec143304d', 'message': 'Use python logging for loguserdata.py, log to console

Python logging is configured with a stream handler and should
also replicate the previous logging to 0600 /var/log/heat-provision.log

By logging to a stream handler cloud-init will write to its log,
which will show up in the server console log. This means that heat
provisioning can now be monitored without needing to log in with:

nova console-log <servername>

This change also touches the file /var/lib/heat-cfntools/provision-finished
instead of also writing a datestamp to it, which is redundant.

Change-Id: Id0312bd2216a83753df601b17ad16d5355cdb11d
'}]
commit_message:
Use python logging for loguserdata.py, log to console

Python logging is configured with a stream handler and should
also replicate the previous logging to 0600 /var/log/heat-provision.log

By logging to a stream handler cloud-init will write to its log,
which will show up in the server console log. This means that heat
provisioning can now be monitored without needing to log in with:

nova console-log <servername>

This change also touches the file /var/lib/heat-cfntools/provision-finished
instead of also writing a datestamp to it, which is redundant.

Change-Id: Id0312bd2216a83753df601b17ad16d5355cdb11d

subject: Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-05-10 17:08:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/35a1c62bc16e46ae2e387ca42cc0885b3e082382', 'message': 'Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

This patch applies a reverse SNAT rule to allow instances on the same
private network to communicate with each other using their floating-ips
in a more consistent fashion. The rule checks if a connection is between
a member of a fixed network with another member of the same fixed
network and a DNAT has occurred. This logic is depending on the initial
DNAT'ing to keep traffic on a private network, so any changes to the
former may require alteration to this code as well. Note that this will
only work for interaction between two servers that both have floating
IPs assigned to them.

The patch addresses this issue by ensuring the target server "sees" an
address that must follow the reverse routing as ensuring that the source
address on the returning packets match the expected target host.

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136

allows members of the same private network to communicate with each

also addresses the situation where the target is on another private

This will only work for interaction between two servers that both have
floating IPs assigned to them.

Specifically, this patch solves the problem where a target server
"sees" the private address of the client. By SNAT'ing to the client's

communication on private networks using private IPs to remain fully

commit_message:
Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

This patch applies a reverse SNAT rule to allow instances that have an
assigned floating IP to communicate with other instances in the same
OpenStack deployment, security group rules permitting. The patch
allows members of the same private network to communicate with each
other using their floating-ips in a more consistent fashion. The rule
also addresses the situation where the target is on another private
network.

This will only work for interaction between two servers that both have
floating IPs assigned to them.

Specifically, this patch solves the problem where a target server
"sees" the private address of the client. By SNAT'ing to the client's
floating-IP, the "sees" the correct reply address and the reverse
route follows the same path that an actual external connection would
take. The SNAT ONLY occurs if a DNAT occurred before hand, allowing
communication on private networks using private IPs to remain fully
private and internal. The limitation is of course if a DNAT occurs for
other reasons, there may be issues.

Resolves bug 1178745

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/28815/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix quantum security group driver to accept none for from/to_port

The quantum security group driver did not accept none values for
from_port/to_port which the nova security group api supports. This
patch allows None values to be passed in for those params and adds a unit test.

In addition the from/to_port responses would be different if using quantum
instead of nova. This patch fixes that and adds unit tests.

Fixes bug 1176027

Change-Id: Id57e253c9dd1787ee25fc5cbb562743692d7abe4

commit_message:
Cells: Don't allow active -> build

Adds support for passing 'expected_vm_state' in an instance_update dict
much like the current support for 'expected_task_state'.

For cells, when the API cell receives an instance update containing a
vm_state of BUILDING, raise an exception if the instance is in some
other state.  This addresses out-of-order messaging issues that can
cause an instance to appear to have a huge delay going ACTIVE.  (A
periodic task run can later heal the state, but it can take a long
while)

Fixes bug 1180283

Change-Id: I64252b30e2596812f3b84da64b1fc8681661d7f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/29215/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Allow the HTTPClient consumer to pass endpoint_type.

The default endpoint_type is None.  With this default, the
ServiceCatalog class -- called by HTTPClient -- chooses adminURL.
This change allows the consumer to pass publicURL, internalURL or some
other endpoint type to override this default behavior.

Fixes: Bug #1176197
Change-Id: I974f0e19caf4fa4fc28ced11e819e803458bd482

commit_message:
make test non executable, otherwise nose skips it

when reading tempest run logs the following can currently be seen:

: INFO: Ignoring files matching ['^\\.', '^_', '^setup\\.py$']
nose.selector: INFO: .../test_endpoints.py is executable; skipped

chmod the files so they get run.

Change-Id: I5e3edb07eec7390877e9ac18b14974730e19088f

commit_message:
Move WaitCondition polling to check_create_complete()

Rather than poll in a loop inside handle_create(), use
check_create_complete() to check the status of the WaitCondition.

Change-Id: I63dc6ec6aeedf3238123334722f86a0f1205f306

We need self.count SUCCESS signals # before we can declare the WaitCondition CREATE_COMPLETE handle_status = handle.get_status() while (FAILURE not in handle_status and len(handle_status) < self.count): logger.debug('Polling for WaitCondition completion,' + ' sleeping for %s seconds, timeout %s' % (self.sleep_time, self.timeout)) eventlet.sleep(self.sleep_time) handle_status = handle.get_status() if FAILURE in handle_status: reason = handle.get_status_reason(FAILURE) elif (len(handle_status) == self.count and handle_status == [SUCCESS] * self.count): logger.debug("WaitCondition %s SUCCESS" % self.name) status = SUCCESS except eventlet.Timeout as t: if t is not tmo: # not my timeout raise else: (status, reason) = (TIMEDOUT, 'Timed out waiting for instance') if status != SUCCESS: raise exception.Error(reason)

commit_message:
Refactor nova.volume.cinder.API to reduce roundtrips with Cinder

Make cinder.API methods accept volume_id instead of the whole volume object.
This will remove redundant roundtrip to get the volume before
passing it to other methods as in fact they only need the id.

Fixes bug 1172297

Change-Id: I5e7f944c1c29b2f211ece2ef86c0959c81e806df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/27537/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Extract getting instance's AZ into a helper module.

An instance's availability zone logic may used by many modules,
so move it from extend API into helper module `nova.availability_zones`.
Also add some tests for the new method.

part of bp: different-availability-zone-filter

Change-Id: I5916a0b09d5dddec338e8e36503953720dfd6bcd

deleted_lines: from nova.openstack.common import memorycache # NOTE(vish): azs don't change that often, so cache them for an hour to # avoid hitting the db multiple times on every request. AZ_CACHE_SECONDS = 60 * 60 def __init__(self): self.mc = memorycache.get_client() def _get_host_az(self, context, instance): host = str(instance.get('host')) if not host: return None cache_key = "azcache-%s" % host az = self.mc.get(cache_key) if not az: elevated = context.elevated() az = availability_zones.get_host_availability_zone(elevated, host) self.mc.set(cache_key, az, AZ_CACHE_SECONDS) return az server[key] = self._get_host_az(context, instance)

commit_message:
Booting a test image doesn't work from documentation

THe documentation registers an image with glance with the name
cirros-0.3-x86_64, but the nova boot command attempts to boot
cirros-0.3.0-x86_64.  This results in nova being unable to find
the image in glance with an error such as:

[user@machine ~(keystone_admin)]$ nova boot --image cirros-0.3.0-x86_64 --flavor m1.small --key_name test my-first-server
ERROR: No image with a name or ID of 'cirros-0.3.0-x86_64' exists.

[user@machine ~(keystone_admin)]$ glance image-show cirros-0.3-x86_64
+------------------+--------------------------------------+
| Property         | Value                                |
+------------------+--------------------------------------+
| checksum         | 50bdc35edb03a38d91b1b071afb20a3c     |
| container_format | bare                                 |
| created_at       | 2013-05-15T01:01:54                  |
| deleted          | False                                |
| disk_format      | qcow2                                |
| id               | 4a190ba0-0767-4152-81ce-a6fb4fc52590 |
| is_public        | True                                 |
| min_disk         | 0                                    |
| min_ram          | 0                                    |
| name             | cirros-0.3-x86_64                    |
| owner            | 6d3ba9f84d294238a0f56f4989fbf595     |
| protected        | False                                |
| size             | 9761280                              |
| status           | active                               |
| updated_at       | 2013-05-15T01:01:54                  |
+------------------+--------------------------------------+

This patch documents registering wtih the full x.y.z
version cirros-0.3.0.

Change-Id: I2070d6425d03a99ce11046188d980a30fdf3cde6

commit_message:
Fix local_settings.py on distributions

On RHEL, Fedora, Scientific Linux, CentOS, etc., the file
/etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings.py (from Ubuntu)
is named /etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings

Fixes bug 1179837

Change-Id: Ia91e6954e9589506823d9b5f8c44877b1d0d488f

revisions:

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-05-15 00:36:54.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/volume/glusterfs.pp', 'spec/classes/cinder_volume_glusterfs_spec.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder/commit/7073e22e506a8c8f18c03903b58d41462be0f11a', 'message': 'Adds GlusterFS Driver

commit_message:
Adds GlusterFS Driver

This patch adds a manifest that configures Cinder to use GlusterFS
as a volume driver.

Change-Id: Ifb874a5c792ac416ec6567bbd70ab291820a04d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/32/29132/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' describe 'cinder::volume::glusterfs' do let :params do { :glusterfs_shares => ['10.10.10.10:/volumes', '10.10.10.11:/volumes'], :glusterfs_shares_config => '/etc/cinder/other_shares.conf', :glusterfs_disk_util => 'du', :glusterfs_sparsed_volumes => 'true', :glusterfs_mount_point_base => '/cinder_mount_point', } end describe 'glusterfs volume driver' do it 'configures glusterfs volume driver' do should contain_cinder_config('DEFAULT/volume_driver').with_value( 'cinder.volume.drivers.glusterfs.GlusterfsDriver') should contain_cinder_config('DEFAULT/glusterfs_shares_config').with_value( '/etc/cinder/other_shares.conf') should contain_cinder_config('DEFAULT/glusterfs_sparsed_volumes').with_value( 'true') should contain_cinder_config('DEFAULT/glusterfs_mount_point_base').with_value( '/cinder_mount_point') should contain_cinder_config('DEFAULT/glusterfs_disk_util').with_value( 'du') should contain_file('/etc/cinder/other_shares.conf').with( :content => "10.10.10.10:/volumes\n10.10.10.11:/volumes\n", :require => 'Package[cinder]', :notify => 'Service[cinder-volume]' ) end end end

Stop granting users GRANT OPTION by default.

Fixes Bug #1180041

Change-Id: Ie683a3ca5d6430c52ead77b41f98fbcb4114ea1e
'}]
commit_message:
Pass None to image if booted from volume in live migration

The destination check in live migration will fetch the image
information from glance and it will throw ImageNotFound if
the instance is booted from volume since there is no image id
on the instance

Fix bug 1170596

Conflicts:

	nova/scheduler/driver.py

Change-Id: Ie683a3ca5d6430c52ead77b41f98fbcb4114ea1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/10/29210/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not instance_ref['image_ref']: image = None else: image = self.image_service.show(context, instance_ref['image_ref'])

subject: xenapi: ensure vdi is not too big when resizing down
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-03-18 19:27:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f6bbf861273fe48a2da991f5827335651b6f1443', 'message': 'xenapi: ensure vdi is not too big when resizing down

Fixes bug 1155066

This check ensures that when a user chooses to resize thier
instance to a smaller size and it is not possible, their
VM is still running, but will be left in the Error state.

Ideally we can report this back to the user without it going
to the Error state, this will be a future change.

Change-Id: Ibad568ab3cfb9caaf4fe002572c8cda973d501a7

Fixes bug 1155066

This change adds a check to ensure that when a user chooses to
resize thier instance to flavor that is too small,
given their current disk usage, the operation fails gracefully.
It will leave their VM running, but in with the status of Error.

Ideally we can report this back to the user without putting the
VM into an Error state, but this will be a future enhancement.
